questions.text: A 40-year-old woman was posted for a modified radical mastectomy with axillary lymph node dissection. During this procedure, the boundary of axillary lymph node dissection was seen as shown in the image. The superior boundary marked as "A" is formed by _________
questions.solution:
The superior boundary of the axillary lymph node dissection area is bounded by the axillary vein.

Boundaries of axillary lymph node dissection are as follows:

  • Superior: Axillary vein
  • Lateral: Thoracodorsal pedicle
  • Medial: Costoclavicular ligament (Halstead ligament)
  • Inferior: Angular vein    

A minimum of 10 lymph nodes is removed during axillary clearance.

questions.text: Three weeks following a parotidectomy,  there is an aberrant regeneration of postganglionic parasympathetic fibers of the nerve marked in the image below.  All the following methods are suitable in order to prevent such occurrence except

choices.text: Artificial membrane between skin and parotid bed

questions.solution:
After parotidectomy, the aberrent regeneration of the postganglionic parasympathetic nerve fibers of the auriculotemporal nerve (marked in the image) leads to Frey's syndrome (gustatory sweating). All the above-mentioned methods are suitable to prevent its occurrence except tympanic neurectomy because it is not a preventive method but is a method of treatment.

Patients with Frey's syndrome present with sweating, warmth, and redness of the face as a result of salivary stimulation by the smell or taste of food.

The diagnosis can be confirmed with a starch-iodine test. This test involves painting the patient’s surgical site with iodine and dry starch, and a stimulus that can cause salivation is given to the patient. In the presence of iodine and sweat, the starch over the affected area will turn blue or brown.

It is an inevitable consequence of parotidectomy unless preventive measures are taken. These measures replace the barrier between the skin and the parotid bed and minimize the abnormal regeneration of autonomic nerve fibers. The preventive measures are:

  • Sternomastoid muscle flap
  • Temporalis fascial flap
  • Insertion of artificial membranes between the skin and the parotid bed.
Treatment of Frey's syndrome is with antiperspirants, tympanic neurectomy, or botulinum toxin injection into the affected area (most effective).

questions.text: Identify the procedure performed to manage a patient with chronic pancreatitis:
questions.solution:
The image shows a distal pancreatectomy with Roux-en-Y pancreaticojejunostomy indicative of the Duval procedure.

It is a drainage procedure for chronic pancreatitis. It was developed on the basis of a presumption that a single stricture of the duct of Wirsung near the ampulla was responsible for the obstructive pathology and terminal drainage would treat the condition.

This procedure has high rates of failure due to restenosis and segmental obstruction of the pancreas due to progressive scarring.

Related Pearl: Surgical procedures for chronic pancreatitis

Duval procedure: Distal pancreatectomy with Roux-en-Y pancreaticojejunostomy

Puestow procedure: Resection of tail followed by longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy

Partington and Rochelle modification of Puestow procedure: Elimination of resection of the pancreatic tail

A longitudinal pancreatotomy shows segmental stenosis of the pancreatic duct and the presence of intraductal calculi in a patient with chronic calcific pancreatitis. Following mobilization of a Roux limb of the jejunum, a longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy is performed to permit extensive drainage of the pancreatic duct system.

Related Pearl: Resection and Hybrid Surgical Procedures for Chronic Pancreatitis

Beger’s procedure: Duodenum-preserving pancreatic head resection (DPPHR)

  • The completed resection after transection of the pancreatic neck and subtotal removal of the pancreatic head, with preservation of the distal common bile duct and duodenum (Marked A).
  • Completion of the reconstruction of the anastomosis to the distal pancreas and to the proximal pancreatic rim by the same Roux limb of the jejunum.

Frey’s procedure:

  • The local resection of the pancreatic head with longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy (LR-LPJ) provides complete decompression of the entire pancreatic ductal system. Reconstruction is performed with a side-to-side Roux-en-Y pancreaticojejunostomy.

Warren’s modification of Beger’s procedure:

Berne modification (Beger + Frey) involves excavation of the central portion of the head without formal division of the neck.

questions.text: Which of the following is a contraindication for performing PAIR technique in hydatid cyst disease?

choices.text: Pregnant woman with CE1 hydatid cyst
Cyst > 5 cm in different liver segments

questions.solution:
A hydatid cyst with honeycomb appearance (CE2) is a contraindication for PAIR (Puncture-Aspiration-Injection-Reaspiration). 

PAIR is unlikely to be successful in CE2 due to the presence of multiple internal septa.

The PAIR technique is performed using either ultrasound or computed tomography (CT) guidance. 

It involves aspiration of the cyst contents via a special cannula, followed by injection of a scolicidal agent for at least 15 minutes, and then reaspiration of the cystic contents. This is repeated until the return is clear. An initial course of albendazole is administered before the procedure. 

When PAIR is contraindicated, surgical resection involving laparoscopic or open complete cystectomy with instillation of a scolicidal agent is preferred and is usually curative. If complete cystectomy is not possible, then anatomic liver resection can be undertaken.

Related Pearl: Indications and contraindications of puncture, aspiration, injection, and re-aspiration (PAIR) in hydatid cyst

Indications:

  • Relapse cyst, infected cyst, cyst >5 cm in different liver segments
  • Patients who refuse surgery or where surgery is contraindicated
  • Pregnant women, children < 3 years of age
  • WHO - type CE1 and type CE3a (transitional cyst)

Contraindications:

  • Cysts in lung
  • Cysts communicating with bile duct
  • Cysts with multiple septae—honeycomb cysts
  • Inaccessible cysts
  • Hyperechogenic cysts
  • Calcified cysts

questions.text: A young boy presented with a cystic swelling on the left side of the floor of the mouth as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and the image of a cystic swelling on the floor of the mouth are suggestive of a ranula.

Ranula is a mucus extravasation cyst arising from the sublingual gland. It produces a characteristic translucent swelling that gives the appearance of a frog’s belly. A ranula usually resolves spontaneously.  

A plunging ranula is a mucus retention cyst. It has mucus collecting below the gland and perforating through the mylohyoid muscle.

Other options:

Options A: Ectopic thyroid tissue is a developmental defect of the thyroid gland and is frequently found along the course of the thyroglossal duct. Lingual thyroid is the most common presentation of ectopic thyroid (shown below).

Option B: Cystic hygroma is usually seen in neonates and early childhood. They are cystic swellings filled with lymph fluid and are characteristically brilliantly translucent. They occur in the neck and can involve the parotid, submandibular, tongue, etc. The swelling is soft and partially compressible. Definitive treatment is the excision of the swelling. 

Option C: Ludwig's angina is a brawny swelling of the submandibular region that is caused by streptococcal infection. The infection tracks down to the mylohyoid muscle causing inflammation that displaces the tongue leading to dysphagia and painful airway obstruction. Management is by antibiotic therapy and decompression of the floor of the mouth by incising mylohyoid muscle.  

Related Pearl: Brilliantly Transilluminating Swellings

  • Vaginal hydrocele
  • Epididymal cyst
  • Cystic hygroma
  • Ranula
  • Meningocele

Related Pearl: Plunging ranula

It is a form of mucous retention cyst that can arise from both sublingual and submandibular salivary glands and presents as dumb-bell-shaped swelling that is soft, fluctuant and painless in the submandibular or submental region of the neck.

  • It shows cross fluctuation along the mylohyoid
  • Treatment is by removal of the sublingual gland and aspiration of the saliva out from the sac. The cervical approach which was previously used is now contraindicated.
  • Conditions with cross fluctuation are :
    • Plunging ranula
    • Bilocular hydrocele
    • Compound palmar ganglion
    • Psoas abscess

Note:

The term ‘ranula’ is applied to a mucous extravasation cyst that arises from the sublingual gland.

questions.text: What is the most common complication of the procedure shown in the picture?
questions.solution:
The image depicts the procedure of endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP). Pancreatitis is the most common complication of ERCP. 

Here in this question image, a side-viewing endoscope is passed through the pylorus of the stomach into the second part of the duodenum to visualize the papilla. It is then cannulated, and dye is injected into the pancreatic or bile duct to visualize the pancreatic or biliary tree.

The pancreatitis is usually mild and resolves in a few days. CT scan is indicated in a patient complaining of pain, tachycardia, or hypotension post-ERCP. The risk factors for the development of post-ERCP pancreatitis include sphincter of Oddi dysfunction, young age, normal bilirubin, past history of pancreatitis, contrast injecting into pancreatic ducts, pancreatic sphincterotomy and balloon dilatation of biliary sphincter.

It is now recommended to administer per-rectal indomethacin or diclofenac before or after the procedure to reduce the risk of post-ERCP pancreatitis.

The other complications of ERCP include duodenal perforation, hemorrhage, and sepsis.

 

Related Pearl: Diagnostic Evaluation of the Bile Ducts

Diagnostic Evaluation of the Bile Ducts

  • Hepatobiliary ultrasound: Initial procedure of choice in investigating possible biliary tract obstruction
  • CT scan: Procedure of choice in investigating possible biliary obstruction if diagnostic limitations prevent HBUS
  • MRCP: Useful modality for visualizing pancreatic and biliary ducts
  • ERCP: Best visualisation of distal biliary tract
    • Endoscopic sphincterotomy and stone removal can also be done
  • PTC(Percutaneous Transhepatic Cholangiography): Best visualisation of proximal biliary tract
    • Indicated when ERCP is contraindicated or failed
  • EUS: Most sensitive method to detect ampullary stones

choices.text: Histopathology shows excess collagen arranged parallel to each other

questions.solution:
The given image shows a keloid scar. The histology of keloid scars shows excess, thick, wavy collagen fibers in random orientation (predominantly type 3 collagen).

Keloid scars are associated with elevated levels of growth factors.

A keloid scar is defined as excessive scar tissue that extends beyond the boundaries of the original incision or wound. Its etiology is unknown, but is associated with elevated levels of growth factor, deeply pigmented skin, and inherited tendencies and certain areas of the body (triangle whose points are the xiphisternum and each shoulder tip).

Keloid scars do not improve spontaneously with time and excision of the keloid scar has a high rate of recurrence.

  • Excision and steroid injections
  • Excision and postoperative radiation (external beam or brachytherapy)
  • Intralesional excision
  • Laser to reduce redness
  • Vitamin E and palm oil massage

questions.text: A patient was rushed to the emergency room after he suffered a lower limb injury in a road traffic accident. You calculate the Mangled extremity severity score, which adds up to a score of 9. What does this score imply?

choices.text: Limb will most likely be salvageable.
Intramedullary nail fixation would be needed at the earliest
Amputation is most likely to be required.
Patient should be reassessed after 6 hours.

questions.solution:
The management of this patient with a mangled extremity severity score (MESS) of 9 is immediate amputation.

MESS can help decide between amputation and limb salvage in crushing injuries.

Components of MESS: mnemonic - ELiSA

  • Energy that caused the injury, skeletal and soft tissue injury
  • Limb ischemia
  • Shock
  • Patient’s Age

The maximal total score is 11. A score of 6 or less is consistent with a salvageable limb. With a score of 7 or greater, amputation is the eventual result.

Other scores to assess if the limb is salvageable or not:

  • Ganga Hospital Open Injury Score (GHOIS)

questions.text: Which among the following images of pressure sores has the highest risk of developing osteomyelitis?
questions.solution:
Image 3 shows complete skin loss that involves muscles and shows exposed bone indicating a Category 4 pressure sore and has the highest risk of developing osteomyelitis.

Pressure sores are skin or soft tissue injuries that occur due to prolonged pressure over specific areas of the body. An external pressure of >30 mmHg leads to the formation of pressure sores. The common sites of pressure sores in decreasing frequency are the ischium, greater trochanter, sacrum, heel, malleolus (lateral followed by medial), and occiput.

The grading system for the description of pressure sores:

Category 1 - Non-blanchable erythema without a breach in the epidermis
Category 2 - Partial-thickness skin loss involving the epidermis and dermis
Category 3 - Full-thickness skin loss extending into the subcutaneous tissue but not through underlying fascia
Category 4 - Full-thickness skin loss through fascia with extensive tissue destruction, maybe involving muscle, bone, tendon, or joint.

Below is the image showing the stages of pressure sore.

Management:

Pressure sores can be prevented with good skincare, the use of air-fluidized beds, special pressure-dispersion cushions, or foams. Repositioning the patient every two hours can lessen the pressure on the area. 

Ulcers of stages I and II often do not require operative measures. The main aim of treatment for pressure ulcers is:

  • To reduce the pressure exerted on the ulcer.
  • Decrease moisture.
  • To keep it as aseptic or least septic as possible.

The ulcer should be cleaned and drained to remove any dead tissue and debris. Good antibiotic cover and hydrocolloid dressing are useful.

Stage 3 and 4 ulcers may require surgical intervention. Surgical management of pressure sores follows the same principles involved in acute wound treatment. Prior to the operation, the pressure sores should be adequately debrided, and vacuum-assisted closure (VAC) can be used to promote the growth of granulation tissue required for surgical closure. Large skin flaps that have muscle with sensory innervation are best for reconstruction.

questions.text:
A patient underwent a TAPP repair for an incarcerated left inguinal hernia. During the procedure, while fixing the mesh, tacks were accidentally placed below the iliopubic tract. On follow-up visits, the patient complained of persistent pain in his lateral thigh. Injury to which of the following nerves has most likely caused the pain?

TAPP repair- Transabdominal preperitoneal repair
questions.solution:
Injury to the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh is the most likely cause of pain in the above scenario.

Lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh lies in the anatomical landmark known as the triangle of pain (as described in the pearl) and can be injured in laparoscopic hernia repair. Any damage to the contents of this structure can lead to chronic pain following hernia repair. 


In laparoscopic TAPP repair, to reduce chances of nerve injury during mesh placement, tacks are ideally placed above the iliopubic tract (away from the triangle of pain which carries the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve, the femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve, and the femoral nerve).

Other options:

Option A: Ilioinguinal nerve may be commonly injured during open hernia repair. It provides innervation to the groin and medial aspect of the thigh, the upper part of the scrotum, and the penile root.

Option B: Iliohypogastric nerve can be injured while making an incision in the right iliac fossa during hernia surgery. It mainly supplies the suprapubic skin.

Option C: Femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve (which supplies the skin over the upper anterior part of the thigh) lies in close relation to the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh. Injury to these also can cause loss of sensation over the thigh but these are less frequent.

questions.text: Stewart-Treves syndrome is characterized by ______.

choices.text: Superficial venous thrombophlebitis of the anterior chest wall

questions.solution:
Stewart-Treves syndrome is characterized by lymphedema-associated angiosarcoma.

This syndrome is observed in the setting of chronic lymphedema after axillary dissection for breast cancer. It develops on an extremity ipsilateral to an axillary lymphadenectomy. It appears on the upper, medial arm as a violaceous plaque with nonpitting edema and has poor survival.

Surgical excision with wide margins is the treatment of choice but the rate of recurrence is high.

Other options:

Option A: Tietze's syndrome is characterized by a benign inflammation of one or more costal cartilages.

Option B: Zuska’s disease, also called recurrent periductal mastitis, is characterized by recurrent retro areolar infections and abscesses.

Option D: Mondor’s disease is characterized by thrombophlebitis of the superficial veins of the breast and anterior chest wall.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding the fluid given in the image below?

choices.text: Used in treatment of increased intracranial pressure.
Hyperchloremic metabolic alkalosis is a possible side effect.
Serum sodium levels should be monitored at regular intervals during its administration.
Concentration of solute is higher compared to plasma and interstitial fluid.

questions.solution:
The fluid shown in the image is hypertonic saline (HS) and hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis is a possible side effect of the administration of HS(not hyperchloremic metabolic alkalosis).

Hypertonic saline is a crystalloid intravenous fluid. It contains sodium chloride dissolved in water with a higher sodium concentration. It has a higher concentration of solute compared to plasma and interstitial fluid

3% and 5% HS is used in the treatment of hyponatremia and increased intracranial pressure. It increases the osmolarity of the blood which shifts the fluid from the extravascular space to the intravascular space. This decreases brain edema and reduces intracranial pressure.

Less volume of HS administration is required to achieve similar plasma volumes as compared to large volumes of normal saline. It also stimulates the release of vasopressin from the pituitary gland, which decreases water loss through the kidneys. Serum sodium and potassium levels should be monitored regularly.  

The most common adverse effects are related to the route of administration such as infection of the IV site, and thrombophlebitis. Due to the addition of NaCl, administration of HS can result in hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis. Rapid correction of severe hyponatremia can result in osmotic demyelination syndrome.

HS should be administered carefully in patients with congestive heart failure or renal insufficiency due to their already increased fluid and sodium loads. Serum sodium levels should be monitored regularly when a bolus of HS is used in the correction of hyponatremia.

questions.text:
Which of the following is most likely to be seen in a patient with hypovolemic shock?

JVP- Jugular Venous Pressure

choices.text: Hypotension with high venous pressure and increased JVP
Hypotension with low venous pressure and normal JVP
Hypotension with  low venous pressure and decreased JVP
Hypotension with low venous pressure and increased JVP

questions.solution:
Hypovolemic shock is most likely to be associated with hypotension, low venous pressure, and decreased JVP (Jugular Venous Pressure).

Shock is a state of circulatory failure resulting in tissue hypoperfusion and hypoxia. Prolonged shock eventually leads to irreversible tissue damage. Shock progresses through a series of well-defined stages:

  1. Initial nonprogressive stage: Compensatory neurohumoral mechanisms come into play to preserve tissue perfusion.
  2. Progressive stage: Tissue hypoperfusion leads to circulatory and metabolic disturbances. Acidosis occurs due to intracellular anaerobic glycolysis. 
  3. Irreversible stage: Tissue injury cannot be reversed even with hemodynamic correction. There is worsening myocardial contractility, renal function impairment, and bacteremia (due to the release of intestinal flora into the circulation).

Hypovolemic shock occurs due to massive hemorrhage or fluid loss from vomiting, diarrhea, and severe burns. This results in low blood volume and cardiac output. Patients present with hypotension, a weak rapid pulse, tachycardia, and cool, clammy, cyanotic skin (due to cutaneous vasoconstriction, which shunts the blood away to vital organs like the heart and brain). More than 90% of otherwise healthy individuals recover with appropriate fluid resuscitation.

Other options:

Option A: Cardiogenic shock is associated with hypotension, high venous pressure, and increased JVP.

Option B: Warm septic shock is associated with hypotension, low venous pressure, and a normal JVP.

Option D: Cold septic shock is associated with hypotension, low venous pressure, and increased JVP.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old female who has an anal fistula is advised for surgery. She browsed about the surgical procedures and came to know that a few procedures may lead to fecal incontinence. She was worried and asks you about the surgeries that does not lead to this complication. Which among the following surgeries allow sphincter preservation?
  1. Video-assisted anal fistula treatment.
  2. Ligation of intersphincteric fistula tract.
  3. Flap advancement.
  4. Fistula tract laser closure.
  5. Over-the-scope clip.
questions.solution:
The surgeries for anal fistula that allow sphincter preservation are:

  • Ligation of intersphincteric fistula tract.
  • Flap advancement.
  • Over-the-scope clip.
  • Video-assisted anal fistula treatment (VAAFT)
  • Fistula tract laser closure (FiLaC)

Ligation of the intersphincteric fistula tract (LIFT) is done at the level of the intersphincteric plane where the internal opening and fistula are disconnected. This is followed by the removal of the residual gland without involving the sphincter complex.

Flap advancement is done for the tracts that are not indurated and adequate intra-anal access can be obtained. The internal opening of the fistula is closed with a well-vascularized flap of anorectal mucosa. This procedure aims at preserving the anatomy and function of the sphincter.

Over-the-scope procedure involves using a nitinol clip and closing the internal opening and disconnecting the external tract. Clip migration and elective removal because of pain are the main complications.

Video-assisted anal fistula treatment (VAAFT) and fistula tract laser closure (FiLaC) are other procedures that allow sphincter preservation.

A fistulotomy is preferred mainly for intersphincteric fistulae and trans-sphincteric fistulae. Here, all structures lying between the external and internal openings are divided. In fistulectomy, the entire fistula tract is removed by diathermy cautery.

The 22-blade is often used for abdominal incisions.

The 15-blade is often used for minor surgical procedures.

In this case, the patient is suffering from Peyronie’s disease. The image shows the traction device/ extender used to treat excessive penile curvature. The most common surgical procedure used in Peyronie’s disease is the Nesbit's procedure.

Peyronie's disease is characterized by penile deformity, palpable penile plaques, erectile dysfunction, and pain on erection. It causes the penis to bend, usually towards the side of the plaque. It can be associated with Dupuytren's contracture as a part of the Galezia triad (Dupuytren's contracture, retroperitoneal fibrosis, peyronie's disease).

Some cases may resolve spontaneously. If not, conservative measures such as oral tamoxifen, vitamin E, terfenadine, intralesional verapamil, etc. can be tried. Intralesional collagenase has also been used. Penile extenders/ traction devices such as that shown in the above image have also been used. However, if none of these methods are effective, surgical management can be tried using Nesbit's procedure.

Nesbit's procedure is indicated when all other interventions have failed and the patient is experiencing difficulty in their sexual and personal life because of it. The procedure is started by creating an artificial erection by injecting normal saline. Following this, an elliptical excision is done on the convex side of the penis (opposite to the thickened plaque). The width of the excised tissue depends on the degree of penile deformity. The side with the plaque is left as it is.

questions.text: A child born to a 38-year-old mother was found to have a round face, flat occiput, protruding tongue, and a 'Simian crease' on the palm. Karyotyping revealed trisomy of chromosome 21. Which of the following anomalies will you most likely see in this child?
questions.solution:
Annular pancreas is more prevalent in children with Down syndrome as given in the scenario above. It is most often seen in association with congenital duodenal stenosis or atresia.

It occurs because of the failure of a complete rotation of the ventral pancreatic bud during development, so a ring of pancreatic tissue surrounds the second or third part of the duodenum. Duodenal obstruction typically causes vomiting in the neonate.

Treatment is duodenoduodenostomy.

Pancreas divisum: When the dorsal and ventral ducts fail to fuse during embryogenesis, it leads to pancreas divisum. As most pancreatic exocrine secretions exit through the dorsal duct, pancreas divisum can lead to partial obstruction caused by a small minor papilla, leading to chronic backpressure in the duct. This relative outflow obstruction can lead to relapsing acute or chronic pancreatitis. The incidence of pancreas divisum in the general population is about 10%.

questions.text: A patient presents with polyuria, polydipsia, lethargy and abdominal pain. He had an X-ray taken a few days ago, which is given below. Which of the following investigations would not be useful in arriving at a diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the X-ray showing nephrocalcinosis is suggestive of primary hyperparathyroidism. Angiography of renal arteries is not a useful investigation for hyperparathyroidism.  

Nephrocalcinosis occurs in this condition due to hypercalcemia. It decreases renal concentrating ability, which may cause polyuria and polydipsia.

Clinical features of hyperparathyroidism:

  • Bones:
    • Pathological fractures
    • Subperiosteal bone resorption - 2nd and 3rd digits, most common in radial aspect
    • Salt and pepper skull
    • Osteitis fibrosa cystica or VonReckling Hausen’s disease of bone
  • Stones
    • Multiple and recurrent renal stones - most common
    • Nephrocalcinosis
  • Abdominal groans - colicky due to pancreatitis
  • Psychiatric overtones - raised PTH causing CNS depression and psychiatric symptoms
  • Band keratopathy
  • Features of hypercalcemia - 
    • Vomiting
    • Confusion
    • ECG changes: increased PR interval, shortened QT interval

 The image given below shows salt and pepper skull seen in hyperparathyroidism.

  • Ultrasonography of the neck is a safe and widely used technique for the localization of abnormal parathyroid glands.  
  • Nuclear medicine scanning with radiolabeled Sestamibi is also a widely used technique. Sestamibi accumulates in parathyroid adenomas. This radionuclide is concentrated in the thyroid and parathyroid tissue but usually washes out of normal thyroid tissue in under an hour. It persists in abnormal parathyroid tissue.  
  • Dual-energy radiographic absorptiometry is a useful tool to demonstrate skeletal involvement in primary hyperparathyroidism.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man presented with headache and vomiting for 7 days and an episode of a tonic-clonic seizure. He had intermittent bloody stools for the past 6 months. He has a family history of colon carcinoma. An MRI of his brain is given below. Colonoscopy and biopsy revealed numerous adenomatous polyps in the rectum and the colon. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the patient has numerous adenomatous polyps and a brain tumour as seen in the MRI. Hence the most likely diagnosis is Turcot's syndrome. It is a variant of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP).

Turcot's syndrome is characterised by malignant tumours of the central nervous system in association with FAP

Familial adenomatous polyposis (option A) is an autosomal dominant condition and is caused due to the mutation in the APC gene located on chromosome 5.

Clinically, patients develop hundreds to thousands of adenomatous polyps in the colon and rectum. More than 100 colonic adenomas are diagnostic of FAP. Some patients may also develop duodenal adenomas. The lifetime risk of developing colorectal carcinoma in these patients is 100%.

The treatment of the FAP includes total proctocolectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis (IPAA)

Gardner's syndrome (option C) is an autosomal dominant variant of FAP. In addition to colonic polyps the patients will have osteomas of the mandible or skull, epidermal cysts and soft tissue tumours like desmoid tumours

In Peutz-Jegher's syndrome, (option D) there is pigmentation of the mouth and lips and multiple hamartomatous polyps in the small and large intestines. It is an autosomal dominant disease.

Related Pearl: Peutz–Jeghers Syndrome

  • Autosomal-dominant disease
  • Germline defects in the tumor suppressor serine-threonine kinase 11 (STK11) gene on chromosome 19.

  • Hyperpigmentation of the buccal mucosa, lips, and digits
  • Hamartomatous polyps of the intestinal tract
  • Increased (2% to 10%) risk for cancer of the intestinal tract (stomach - rectum).
  • Increased risk for extraintestinal malig­nant neoplasms, including cancer of the breast, ovary, cervix, fallopian tubes, thyroid, lung, gallbladder, bile ducts, pancreas, and testicles.

Screening: Baseline colonoscopy and upper endoscopy at age 20 years, followed by annual flexible sigmoidoscopy thereafter.

  • Gastric and duodenal polyps are present
  • Gastric polyp: fundal gland polyp, gastric adenoma
  • Duodenal polyp usually in the ampullary region: Adenomatous and premalignant

  • Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE) is seen. It is detected by indirect ophthalmoscopy.
  • Epidermoid cysts
  • Desmoid tumors in the abdomen
  • Osteoma in the skull, mandible, and tibia
  • Brain tumors
  • Tumors of the thyroid, adrenal, liver, pancreas, gallbladder, and bile duct

questions.text:
A patient is brought to the emergency room with polytrauma. Which of the following is not considered as an adjunct to the primary survey?

AP- Anteroposterior

PA- Posteroanterior
questions.solution:
Chest X-ray PA view is not a part of a primary survey. Chest X-ray is done in AP view in primary survey of trauma care.

The steps in the ATLS (Advanced Trauma Life Support):

  • Primary survey with simultaneous resuscitation – identify and treat life-threatening conditions.
  • Secondary survey – proceed to identify all other injuries
  • Definitive care – develop a definitive management plan

ABCDE of trauma care:

  • Airway assessment and protection (maintain cervical spine stabilization when appropriate). If airway obstruction is identified, jaw thrust in cervical injury patients or chin lift is performed.
  • Breathing and ventilation assessment (maintain adequate oxygenation)
  • Circulation assessment (control hemorrhage and maintain adequate end-organ perfusion). Two wide-bore (14G to 16G) cannulae are inserted for intravenous fluid resuscitation.
  • Disability assessment (perform basic neurologic evaluation). This is most commonly assessed by the Glasgow coma scale along with pupil reactivity score (GCS-P).
  • Exposure, with environmental control (undress patient and search everywhere for possible injury, while preventing hypothermia)

Adjuncts to the primary survey: These help in the evaluation of other life-threatening processes.

Monitoring- 

  • Electrocardiograph (ECG) is done to evaluate cardiac dysrhythmias, myocardial infarction, and cardiac tamponade.
  • Continuous cardiac monitoring to detect any changes in heart rate and rhythm.
  • Continuous oxygen monitoring via pulse oximetry.
  • Ventilation monitoring via capnography and arterial blood gas analysis.

Catheters-

  • Urinary catheters help in the evaluation of fluid status.
  • Gastric catheters decompress the stomach and reduces the risk of aspiration.

Imaging-

  • Trauma triple radiographs of the cervical spine, chest, and pelvis, even in pregnant women. 
    • Cervical spine lateral view to look for spinal injury.
    • Chest AP view is done to evaluate for pneumothorax, hemothorax, rib fractures, or aortic injury.
    • Pelvis AP view to evaluate for pelvic fractures.
  • Ultrasound FAST Examination is the "Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma". It is performed to detect pericardial and intraperitoneal blood. The Extended FAST (E-FAST) includes examination of the thoracic cavity.
  • Diagnostic peritoneal lavage (DPL) is done to detect intraperitoneal bleed.
  • Emergency computed tomography (CT)

These specialised forms of imaging, such as ultrasound, computerised tomography, angiography, and diagnostic peritoneal lavage, should be considered after the secondary survey, and only when the patient is stable after initial resuscitation.

Laboratory studies-

  • Arterial blood gas (ABG) to assess oxygentaion, ventilation, and pH.
  • Blood typing and grouping for blood transfusion.
  • Complete blood count and coagulation studies in anemic patients or patients using anticoagulation drugs.
  • Pregnancy test in any woman of child-bearing age.
  • Urinalysis in pelvic or abdominal trauma.
  • Urea and electrolytes, blood glucose levels, and toxicology studies in patients with unexplained altered mental status.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents to the surgery OPD with a constellation of features such as impotence, buttock claudication, and absence of femoral pulses. The image below shows the findings seen in the leg. In which of the following conditions are the patient's features seen?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Leriche syndrome.

Leriche syndrome is a rare form of aortoiliac occlusive disease (AIOD) that presents with the triad of intermittent claudication, erectile dysfunction, and absent femoral pulses.

Obstruction of the superficial femoral artery causes claudication of the buttock or thigh. Absent distal pulses, bruit over the aortoiliac region, and associated or isolated discomfort of the calf can also be seen.

Investigations that are useful include Doppler ultrasound, duplex scanning, ankle-brachial pressure index, and digital subtraction percutaneous angiography (DSA).

Management is by exercise, smoking cessation, control of diabetes, and weight loss if obese. Drugs such as HMG CoA reductase inhibitors and 75 mg of clopidogrel or aspirin should be given. Transluminal angioplasty and stenting are useful.

The other options are sound-alike signs/syndromes.

Lemmel syndrome: This is obstructive jaundice caused by a periampullary duodenal diverticulum compressing the intrapancreatic part of the common bile duct, with resultant upstream dilatation of the extra- and intrahepatic bile ducts.

Lhermitte sign: This refers to shooting electric shock-like sensations in the lower extremities when the neck is maximally flexed in patients with cervical radiculopathy.

Lemierre syndrome is septic thrombophlebitis of the internal jugular vein. This is a rare and potentially fatal complication of an oropharyngeal infection. The organism involved is typically a fusiform bacillus. The condition presents with severe neck pain, septicemia, or a prolonged fulminant course in a patient with an infection of the upper aerodigestive tract.

Related Pearl: Ankle–brachial Pressure Index (ABPI)

The ankle-brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) is the ratio of systolic pressure at the ankle to that in the arm.

The numerator is the highest pressure in the dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial, or peroneal artery and the denominator is the highest brachial systolic pressure.

ABPI Reading Interpretation
>0.9 to <1.4 Normal
<0.9 Diagnostic of occlusive arterial disease in patients with symptoms of claudication or other signs of ischemia
0.5 to 0.9 Arterial obstruction often associated with claudication
<0.4 Critical limb ischemia (multilevel obstruction i.e any combination of iliac, femoral or tibial vessel disease and may be associated with non-healing ulcerations, ischemic rest pain, or pedal gangrene.
>1.4 Signifies poor compressibility of the arteries. Mostly due to calcification because of increased age, diabetes etc.

Note: A fall in the resting ABPI of more than 20% after exercise is indicative of arterial disease.

questions.text: A 28-year-old anxious male comes to the urology OPD with a chronic history of deformity of the penis and pain on erection. He is subjected to the USG of the penis, the findings of which are as shown below. Which of the following associated is not a part of the classical Galezia's triad expected to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient is suffering from Peyronie’s disease. The image shows the penile calcifications of the corpus cavernosum. Erectile dysfunction is a complication of Peyronie's disease and not a component of Galezia's triad.

Galezia triad conisits of:

  • Retroperitoneal fibrosis
  • Dupuytren's contracture 
  • Peyronie's disease

Peyronie's disease is characterized by penile deformity, palpable penile plaques within the penis, erectile dysfunction, and pain on erection. It causes the penis to bend, usually towards the side of the plaque. It can be associated with Dupuytren's contracture.

The active phase is characterized by changes in penile curvature or deformity and pain with erection. Stable disease is characterized by the absence of pain and nonprogression of deformity. The diagnosis is usually made on clinical examination but MRI may be helpful.

Verapamil intralesional drug therapy and collagenase clostridium histolyticum (CCH) intralesional drug therapy are safe and well tolerated treatment options. Penile traction therapy, usually in conjunction with medical management, has shown some efficacy.

In severe deformity and calcifications, surgical options are preferred. Nesbitt's procedure corrects the deformity by plicating the opposite side of the deformity, thereby straightening the penis. This procedure is done once the active phase subsides as the bend increases during the active phase (18-24 months).  The treatment will shorten the erect penile length.

questions.text:
During a central line insertion, the patient suffers a pleural puncture and develops breathing difficulty and sharp pain. There is an absence of breath sounds on the right side. A chest X-ray is done and appears as shown below. A needle is inserted in the 2nd intercostal space as an emergency measure. However, the breathing difficulty persists and a decision to insert an intercostal drain is taken. You would insert the chest drain into the triangle that lies _________.
  1. Posterior to the midaxillary line
  2. Anterior to the mid-axillary line
  3. Above the level of the nipple
  4. Below the level of the nipple
  5. Above and Medial to the pectoralis muscle
  6. Below and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and chest X-ray is suggestive of tension pneumothorax. The safest site for insertion of a chest drain is the triangle of safety which lies:

  • Anterior to the mid-axillary line;
  • Above the level of the nipple;
  • Below and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle.

This will be present in the fifth intercostal space.

Pneumothorax refers to the collection of air between the lung and chest wall causing the lung to collapse. Tension pneumothorax develops when a "one-way valve" air leak occurs either from the lung or through the chest wall. Air is sucked into the thoracic cavity without any means of escape, completely collapsing and then compressing the affected lung.

Tension pneumothorax is characterized by chest pain, tachypnea, tachycardia, hypotension, tracheal deviation away from the side of injury, unilateral absence of breath sound, cyanosis, and neck vein distension.

Tension pneumothorax is a clinical diagnosis, and treatment should never be delayed waiting for radiological confirmation.

Treatment consists of immediate decompression, initially by rapid insertion of a large-bore cannula on the affected side.

Due to the variable thickness of the chest wall, kinking of the catheter, and other technical or anatomic complications, needle decompression may not always be successful. In this case, finger thoracostomy is an alternative approach and is recommended as the next best step. 

Tube thoracostomy is mandatory after needle or finger decompression of the chest and is the definitive management.

The technique of drain insertion includes the following:

  • The area should be thoroughly sterilized before the procedure.
  • Adequate local anesthesia to include the pleura.
  • Sharp dissection should be done to cut only the skin.
  • Blunt dissection with artery forceps down through the muscle layers; which involve the serratus anterior and the intercostals.
  • An oblique tract is made so that the skin incision and the hole in the parietal pleura do not overlie each other and so that the drain is in a short tunnel, which reduces the chance of entraining air.
  • A drain for pneumothorax and haemothorax should aim towards the apex of the lung.
  • A drain for pleural effusion or empyema should be nearer the base.
  • The drain should pass over the upper edge of the rib to avoid injury to the neurovascular bundle that lies beneath the rib. 
  • A vertical mattress suture is inserted for later wound closure. This is important for pneumothorax management but not required if the drain is for empyema (provided there is the adherence of the pleura) because that tract should lie open.
  •  The drain should be connected to an underwater seal device which functions as a one-way valve.
  • Do not attach to a suction device at another end because it may worsen the air leak if the lung is fragile or might even cause a shift of mediastinum if the lung doesn't expand well
  • After completion, check the position of the drain by taking a chest radiograph.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man presents to the casualty with a severe headache, fever, and vomiting for the past 5 hours. A CT of the head is shown below. Physical examination shows positive Kernig’s and Brudzinski’s signs. Vitals: Temp: 101 F, BP: 120/88 mmHg, and pupils are reactive. Which of the following statements regarding the condition is false?
  1. Hess and Hunt's scale is used to grade the severity of this condition
  2. Most common spontaneous cause for this condition is the rupture of a berry aneurysm.
  3. Nifedipine is recommended for all patients with this condition.
  4. Triple H therapy is used which includes hypothermia, hypertension and hypervolemia.
  5. The treatment of choice is surgical clipping.
questions.solution:
These patient's clinical features are suggestive of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). CT reveals blood in the cistern. Combined with clinical manifestations of severe headache, neck rigidity, and absent focal neurological defect, the most likely diagnosis is subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH).

CT shows hyperattenuating material filling the subarachnoid space. This is suggestive of SAH. Most commonly, it occurs around the circle of Willis due to the rupture of a berry aneurysm at this location.

SAH:

The most common cause of SAH is trauma. The most common spontaneous cause of SAH is the rupture of berry aneurysms.

Clinically presents as a thunderclap headache, neck rigidity, transient loss of consciousness, no focal neurological deficit. SAH can mostly present with fever, positive Kernig’s sign, and Brudzinski’s sign, as well as mimic meningitis or encephalitis.

Although sudden headache in the absence of focal neurological symptoms is the hallmark of aneurysmal rupture, focal neurological deficits may occur.

A painful third nerve palsy is typically the result of compression from a posterior communicating artery aneurysm. Intraocular hemorrhages, classically subhyaloid, may be visible on fundoscopy. The combination of SAH and vitreous hemorrhage is known as Terson’s Syndrome. 

Diagnosis - Non-contrast CT head, lumbar puncture shows xanthochromia. Xanthochromia refers to the yellowish appearance of CSF. In a lumbar puncture, a traumatic tap can be confused with subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) as both show blood in the CSF withdrawn. Non-contrast CT shows blood in the basal cistern. CT angiography has a high sensitivity for aneurysms and AVMs, but digital subtraction angiography remains the gold standard.

The treatment of choice for subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is surgical clipping.  Nimodipine is indicated to relieve a neurological deficit occurring secondary to cerebral vasospasm following subarachnoid hemorrhage. It is a member of the dihydropyridine group of calcium channel blockers and causes vasodilation in cerebral blood vessels. It is lipid-soluble and has a high affinity for cerebral blood vessels and appears to reduce morbidity after subarachnoid hemorrhage.

In patients with symptomatic vasospasm, triple H therapy is added as part of the therapeutic regimen. It does not include hypothermia. 

  • Induced hypertension- with vasopressors to maintain cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP).
  • Hypervolemia- to maintain the circulatory blood volume 
  • Hemodilution- accompanying change due to fluid therapy.

Hess and Hunt's scale is the most widely used scale to the grade of severity of subarachnoid hemorrhage.

Grade Description
1 Asymptomatic or minimal headache and slight nuchal rigidity
2 Moderate to severe headache, nuchal rigidity, cranial nerve palsy only
3 Drowsy, confusion, or mild focal deficit
4 Stupor, moderate to severe hemiparesis, possibly early decerebrate rigidity
5 Deep coma, decerebrate rigidity, moribund appearance

The World Federation of Neurological Surgeons (WFNS) grading of subarachnoid hemorrhage considers two parameters:

  • Glasgow coma scale
  • Presence or absence of focal neurological deficit(in the form of dysphasia/limb weakness).

WFNS grading is as follows:

Grade Glasgow Coma Scale Focal deficits
I 15 –
II 13–14 –
III 13–14 +
IV 7–12 ±
V 3–6 ±

questions.text: A 38-year-old male presents to the emergency room with nausea,  vomiting, and acute onset epigastric pain, which is severe, constant, and refractory to the usual doses of analgesics. The pain typically radiates to the back and is slightly relieved in the sitting forward position. The following signs are seen on examination. All of the following is used for assessing the severity of the given condition except
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario with the Grey Turner sign (A) and Cullen's sign (B) shown in the picture, is suggestive of acute pancreatitis. All the above criteria can be used for assessing the severity of Acute pancreatitis except Rosemont’s criteria.

Rosemont’s criteria is used for the diagnosis of chronic pancreatitis and is based on endoscopic ultrasonographic (EUS) findings. 

Revised Atlanta classification is used for assessing severity of acute pancreatitis.

Atlanta classification:

Mild Acute Pancreatitis

  • No organ failure
  • No local or systemic complications

Moderately Severe Acute Pancreatitis

  • Transient organ failure (<48 hours) and/or
  • Local or systemic complications without persistent organ failure

Severe Acute Pancreatitis

  • Persistent organ failure (>48 hours)–single organ or multiorgan

Related Pearl: Clinical Features of Acute Pancreatitis

Symptoms:

  • Acute onset of epigastric pain, which is severe, constant, and refractory to usual doses of analgesics.
  • Typically radiates to back
  • Relieved in the sitting forward position
  • Nausea, repeated vomiting, retching, and hiccups

Signs:

  • Hypotension, tachycardia, and tachypnea
  • Grey Turner sign (A): Bluish discoloration of the flanks
  • Cullen’s sign (B): Bluish discoloration around the umbilicus
  • Fox sign: Discolouration below the inguinal ligament
  • Pleural effusion (left > right): Dullness on percussion, decreased breath sounds

Related Pearl: Assessment of severity of acute pancreatitis

  • Bedside Index for Severity of Acute Pancreatitis (BISAP) includes:
    • Blood urea nitrogen, > 25 mg/dL
    • Impaired mental status, Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score <15
    • Systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS)
    • Age > 60 years
    • Pleural effusion
      One point is given for each. BISAP score ≥ 3 indicates severe pancreatitis.
  • Harmless Acute Pancreatitis Score (HAPS)
    If all the following are present then it is considered non-severe, i.e., no death, no need for dialysis, and no need for ventilation:
    • Absence of rebound tenderness or guarding
    • Normal hematocrit
    • Normal serum creatinine

  • Acute Physiology and Chronic Health Evaluation (APACHE II)
    • A score of 8 or more is considered to be severe
    • Can be done at admission and repeated any time
    • Complex, not specific for AP, and based on the patient’s age
  • Ranson’s score
  • Modified Glasgow criteria - 3 or more positive criteria, the disease is considered to be severe
  • Atlanta classification

questions.text: A  patient with appendicular mass is managed by the Ochsner-Sherren regimen. After 24 hours, the patient complaints of increased abdominal pain. On CT examination the size of the mass is found to be increased. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Increasing the dose of analgesics and watch for spontaneous resolution.
Increasing the dose of both antibiotics & analgesics and watch for spontaneous resolution.

questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient's condition is worsening, and CT reveals an increase in the size of the mass. Immediate surgical intervention should be done in this patient.

Ochsner–Sherren regimen is indicated for patients with appendicular mass in whom conditions are stable.

The patient's temperature and pulse rate are recorded 4-hourly and adequate fluid balance is maintained. CECT abdomen is done and antibiotic therapy is started. Abscess if present is drained. Improvement is usually seen within 24–48 hours.

If the patient's condition deteriorates or if there is evidence of peritonitis, laparotomy is performed.

Criteria to stop conservative treatment of an appendicular mass:

  • Rising pulse rate.
  • Increasing or spreading abdominal pain
  • Increase in size of the mass.

 

Related Pearl: Oshner Sherren Regimen

Principle :

  • The inflammatory process is already localised and that inadvertent surgery is difficult and may be dangerous.
  • It may be impossible to find the appendix and, occasionally, a faecal fistula may form.
  • Antibiotic therapy should be given after performing CECT abdomen
  • Abscess if present can be drained radiologically.

Outcome :

  • Improvement in 24–48 h
  • 90% cases resolve
  • Failure should raise suspicion of Crohn’s disease and carcinoma. 

Criteria for stopping conservative treatment of Appendicular mass:

  • Rising pulse rate
  • Increasing or spreading abdominal pain
  • Increasing size of the mass

A 57-year-old male patient with a history of liver cirrhosis presents to the emergency department with massive hematemesis. He is resuscitated and stabilized. Which of the following is the preferred option to prevent rebleeding?

TIPSS- Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt
questions.solution:
The preferred treatment option to prevent rebleeding is endoscopic band ligation.

In this method, a rubber band that can constrict is placed at the base of the varix. This immediately occludes the vessel and stops the bleeding. Rebleeding occurs very rarely with this method. 

Initial management of variceal bleeding involves the following: 

  • Admission to the intensive care unit
  • Placement of two large-bore peripheral cannulae
  • Blood transfusion
  • Correction of coagulopathy with fresh frozen plasma, vitamin K and tranexamic acid
  • Terlipressin, a splanchnic vasoconstrictor
  • Prophylactic antibiotic
  • Endotracheal intubation for airway protection if bleeding is uncontrolled
  • Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy

Other options

Option B - Endoscopic sclerotherapy involves injecting a sclerosant around the bleeding vessel. It is also effective in treating esophageal varices. However, the incidence of rebleeding is higher with this treatment.

Option C - Sengstaken-Blakemore tube is a temporary, stabilizing measure.  It tamponades the bleeding varices. It is not a definitive treatment for variceal bleeding but is very effective to stop the bleed and stabilize the patient.

Option D - TIPSS or transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic stent shunt placement involves the placement of a shunt to redirect blood flow and reduce portal pressure. It is very effective but requires analgesia, sedation, and fluoroscopic guidance. It is done if medical and endoscopic measures fail to control bleeding.

Related Pearl: Common sites of porto-systemic anastomosis in portal hypertension

  • Left gastric vein [portal] to Distal oesophageal [systemic] veins: Presents with oesophageal and gastric variceal bleeding
  • Superior rectal veins to Middle and inferior rectal veins: Presents with rectal varices and lower GI tract bleeding
  • Tributaries of left branch of portal vein in ligamentum teres to Periumbilical branches of epigastric and intercostal veins: Forms caput medusae
  • Tributaries of right branch of portal vein overlying ‘bare area’ of liver to Retroperitoneal veins draining into azygos, hemiazygos, lumbar, intercostal and phrenic veins
  • Omental and colonic veins near hepatic and splenic ﬂexures to Retroperitoneal veins near hepatic and splenic ﬂexures

Related Pearl: Causes of Portal Hypertension

questions.text: A 61-year-old man presents with complaints of fatigue and shortness of breath. He has conjunctival pallor and has lost significant weight over 3 months. A CBC reveals low haemoglobin and MCV. A stool occult blood test is positive. What is the next best step in evaluation?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of an elderly patient with sudden onset anemia always warrants screening for colorectal cancer, as cancers in the right colon often manifest as melena and fatigue associated with anemia. Thus, the next best investigation is a colonoscopy.

Colonoscopy is the investigation of choice & gold standard for establishing the diag­nosis of colon cancer.

It permits biopsy of the tumor to verify the diagnosis while allowing inspection of the entire colon to exclude metachronous polyps or cancers.

Colonoscopy is generally performed even after cancer is detected by barium enema, in order to obtain a biopsy specimen and to detect (and remove) small polyps that may have been missed in the contrast study.

questions.text: Radiological investigations of a patient with a groin hernia revealed a portion of the wall of the hernia sac is formed by the colon along with a defect in the posterior wall.  According to Nyhus classification, what is the type of groin hernia is seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
In the above case, as the colon (internal organ) composes a portion of the wall of the hernial sac is suggestive of a sliding type of indirect inguinal hernia. According to Nyhus classification, a posterior wall defect along with sliding hernia is classified as type III.

A sliding type of indirect inguinal hernia occurs when an internal organ composes a portion of the wall of the hernia sac. The most common viscus is involved in the colon or urinary bladder.

Related Pearl: Nyhus classification of groin hernia

  • Type I - Indirect inguinal hernia: internal inguinal ring normal (e.g., pediatric hernia)
  • Type II - Indirect inguinal hernia: internal inguinal ring dilated but posterior inguinal wall intact; inferior deep epigastric vessels not displaced
  • Type III - Posterior wall defect
    • A- Direct inguinal hernia
    • B - Indirect inguinal hernia: internal inguinal ring dilated, medially encroaching on or destroying the transversalis fascia of Hesselbach triangle (e.g., scrotal, sliding, or pantaloon hernia)
    • C - Femoral hernia
  • Type IV - Recurrent hernia
    • A - Direct
    • B - Indirect
    • C - Femoral
    • D - Combined

questions.text: Technetium-99m pertechnetate scintigraphy done for a patient with a chronic painless facial swelling is shown below. Which of the following statements is false regarding this tumor?

choices.text: This tumor has no malignant potential
Superficial parotidectomy is the treatment of choice
Histology shows a double layer of epithelial cells with dense lymphoid stroma
It is the most common unilateral benign tumor of the parotid gland

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image are suggestive of Warthin’s tumor. These tumors appear as hot spots on radionuclide scans because of the high mitochondrial content in oncocytes that incorporate technetium-99m. The most common benign tumor of the parotid gland is pleomorphic adenoma.

Warthin’s tumor or papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum usually presents as a unilateral tumor.  It is usually seen in the lower poles of the parotid and is commonly associated with smoking. It occurs most often in elderly males. It has no malignant potential.   

Histology shows tumor cells lined by a double layer of neoplastic epithelial cells resting on the dense lymphoid stroma. FNAC is the preferred investigation. Superficial parotidectomy is the treatment of choice.

Note: Both pleomorphic adenoma and Warthin's tumors commonly present as unilateral tumors. A bilateral presentation is usually rare. However in rare cases, if there is a bilateral benign salivary tumor, the tumor is most likely to be a Warthin's tumor.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding incisions?

choices.text: Incisions made on the basis of natural body creases reduce tension on the suture line.
Incisions are avoided over the bony prominences.
Circular incisions are preferred over elliptical incisions to achieve a tension-free approximation.
Incisions made on the basis of natural body creases can camouflage scars

questions.solution:
Elliptical incisions are preferred over circular ones for tension-free, aesthetic tissue approximation.

Incisions over the skin are made using a scalpel with the blade, pressed down at right angles to the skin surface, and gently drawn across the skin in the desired direction. The 22-size blade is commonly used for abdominal incisions

Factors that are considered while planning skin incisions are:

  • Langer’s lines that represent the dermal collagen fibers are used as a guide in skin incision placement. In daily practice, incisions are placed, based on the natural body creases and wrinkles. This reduces the tension on the suture line and camouflage scars.
  • Incisions are avoided over the bony prominences. Underlying structures such as nerves and vessels should be considered while placing an incision.
  • Incision must be functionally adequate. No compromise should be done for cosmetic purposes as it may render the operation ineffective.
  • An elliptical incision is preferred over a circular incision for tension-free, aesthetic tissue approximation. The elliptical incision should be three times as long as it is wide for the wound to heal without tension.

questions.text: An elderly hypertensive male presented with a sudden onset tearing type of chest pain shooting to the neck and interscapular region. He was started on anti-hypertensives. A CT chest of the patient showed aortic dissection limited to the descending aorta. The patient had persistent pain despite adequate medical therapy. What is the preferred management for this patient?

choices.text: Strict control of blood pressure using beta blockers.
Emergency graft replacement of the descending aorta.

questions.solution:
The patient presents with aortic dissection limited to the descending aorta. As his pain fails to settle despite therapy, he comes under the complicated Stanford type B classification. Percutaneously placed endovascular stent is currently the management of choice over open surgical management in complicated Stanford Type B dissections.

Type III DeBakey/ Stanford Type B dissection is usually managed conservatively. The intervention is indicated in complicated cases with features of:

  • Worsening chest pain indicating imminent rupture or failure of resolution of pain
  • The progressive expansion of lesion on serial chest imaging (radiograph or CT scan)
  • Malperfusion syndrome results in organ dysfunction, such as renal failure, or limb and neurological complications.

Acute aortic dissection can be classified by the original DeBakey system, based on the location of the proximal tear and distal extent of the dissection flap, or the Stanford system which uses the location of the proximal tear alone.

Site of dissection DeBakey Stanford

Only ascending aorta and arch of aorta Type II Type A

Descending the aorta distal to the subclavian artery

Type IIIa

Limited to the thoracic aorta

Type IIIb

Extends to the abdominal aorta

Aortic dissection occurs when a defect or flap occurs in the intima of the aorta.

Predisposing factors: 

  1. Age
  2. Hypertension
  3. Marfan syndrome
  4. Pregnancy
  5. Other connective tissue disorders, for example, Ehlers–Danlos syndrome, giant cell arteritis, systemic lupus erythematosus
  6. Coarctation of the aorta
  7. Turner or Noonan syndromes
  8. Aortic cannulation site (iatrogenic). 

The most typical presentation of aortic dissection is a tearing interscapular pain. The dissection may also result in aortic wall rupture into the pericardium (cardiac tamponade) or mediastinum (left haemothorax).

Contrast-enhanced CT is currently the most preferred imaging modality for aortic dissection. Double-lumen aorta is seen on CECT. Transesophageal echocardiography is preferred for patients who are unstable for transportation.

The initial management of patients with all types of aortic dissection is beta-blocker medication to control hypertension, along with pain management. The preferred beta-blocker drug is esmolol.

Treatment options:

  • Stanford Type A (DeBakey Types I and II) requires surgical intervention once the patient's blood pressure is stabilized.
  • Stanford Type B (DeBakey type III) is best managed by antihypertensive drugs. For patients with complicated type B dissection, percutaneously placed endovascular stents are currently preferred. Surgery is reserved for the rare patients not suitable for stenting.

questions.text:
A female patient diagnosed with parathyroid adenoma was posted for parathyroidectomy. After the removal of the gland, her intra-operative PTH level was measured and is shown in the graph below. What is the next step in management?

PTH- Parathyroid hormone

Normal Range of PTH - 10-65 pg/mL

choices.text: Autotransplant the parathyroid tissue in the forearm.
Check the level of PTH again.

questions.solution:
The graph shows the values of PTH before and after the excision of the gland. Here the values have dropped from 142 (Pre-incision) to 25 (10 minutes post-excision). The drop indicates a fall of the values into the normal range and to less than half the maximum preoperative PTH levels, indicating that it is likely to be a single-gland disease as per the Miami criteria. Hence, no further surgical intervention is required.

The Miami criteria were developed to ensure the adequacy of resection in parathyroid surgery. It is based on the principle that the half-life of the PTH is 3-5 minutes. In a single-gland disease, once the gland is removed the PTH levels should drop to the normal range and to less than half the maximum preoperative PTH at 10 minutes.

Most of the patients with primary hyperparathyroidism have a single adenoma and therefore undergo a focused or minimally invasive parathyroidectomy, where the localized abnormal parathyroid gland is removed through an incision less than 3 cm. Once the gland is removed, the surgeon can ensure no other hyperactive gland remains by performing an intraoperative PTH assay which is interpreted based on the Miami criteria.

However, if there is no drop in PTH level, then a multi-gland disease is suspected and the surgery is converted to a bilateral neck exploration. At times during bilateral neck exploration, all four glands are removed and a forearm autotransplant of parathyroid tissue in the brachioradialis muscle is done.

questions.text: A surgical team plans for liver transplantation in a child. As a part of the evaluation, you are asked to calculate the Child-Turcotte-Pugh score. Which of the following parameters would you not consider for the evaluation of this score?
questions.solution:
Creatinine is not included in the Child–Turcotte–Pugh Score or Child-Pugh scoring system. Creatinine is used in the MELD score calculation.

The variables taken into account for the calculation of the Child-Turcotte-Pugh score include serum bilirubin, albumin, prothrombin time, International Normalized ratio, and clinical signs suggestive of the presence of ascites and encephalopathy. 

The Child-Pugh score is a predictor of operative mortality in patients with cirrhosis and esophageal bleeding. It is now used to estimate a patient’s overall prognosis. 

Alternative scores include the Model for End-Stage Liver Disease (MELD) and Pediatric End-Stage Liver Disease (PELD) models for all patients with chronic liver disease. The MELD score is calculated using serum sodium, serum creatinine, serum total bilirubin, and INR level.

The PELD model for children under 12 years of age, includes both clinical and biochemical factors. It is predictive of disease severity and waiting list mortality in pediatric patients. The PELD score is calculated using the following variables:

  • Albumin (g/dL)
  • Bilirubin (mg/dL)
  • INR
  • Growth failure (based on gender, height, and weight)
  • Age at listing

questions.text: During abdominoperineal resection (APR), the given instrument was used to separate the edges of the abdominal wall. Identify the instrument:
questions.solution:
The above image is that of a Goligher retractor. 

Goligher retractor is a self-retaining retractor used in operations on the sigmoid colon and rectum, such as anterior resection and the upper end of abdominoperineal resection. The retractor is inserted with the side blades to separate the edges of the abdominal wall. The central blade is then inserted to keep the small bowel away from the operation site.

Option B: Dyball retractor is used in major abdominal surgeries to retract deeper parts of the abdominal wall, bladder, or uterus while operating on the rectum and entering the rectovesical or rectouterine pouch. It has a lip at the bottom of the blade to prevent slippage. Care should be taken when it is used to retract the liver as it may damage the liver parenchyma.

Option C: Travers retractor is a self-retaining retractor used for intermediate-type operations, such as:

  • Herniorrhaphy
  • Groin dissection for varicose veins
  • Femoral embolectomy.

Option D- Langenbeck retractor is used for holding open wounds, as in an open appendicectomy. It is often used in pairs with one retractor in each of the assistant’s hands. The width of the lip of the retractors varies.

questions.text: In what condition would you see the gallbladder as shown below?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a strawberry gallbladder. Strawberry gallbladder is seen in cholesterolosis and is associated with cholesterol stones.

Cholesterolosis is characterized by mucosal villous hyperplasia. The interior of the gallbladder resembles a strawberry. The yellow specks are aggregations of cholesterol crystals and cholesterol esters in the lamina propria. This corresponds to the seeds of a strawberry.

Option A: Cholesterol polyposis - Cholecystography or ultrasonography shows negative shadows in a functioning gallbladder, indicating the presence of a well-defined polyp.

Options B and C: Cholecystitis glandularis proliferans/adenomyomatosis - All layers of the gallbladder wall may be thickened, but sometimes, an incomplete septum forms that separate the hyperplastic from the normal layer. Intraparietal "mixed" calculi may be present.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presents to the emergency room with sudden pain in his scrotum associated with fever. His condition rapidly progressed and his scrotum appears as below. His past medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus for which he is taking canagliflozin. IV fluids are started and vital signs are noted to be stable. What is the next best step in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and image findings of cellulitis of the testis are suggestive of Fournier's gangrene. The next best step in the management of this condition is IV fluids, intravenous antibiotics, and urgent surgical excision.

Fournier's gangrene - 

It is a polymicrobial infection and a type of necrotizing fasciitis of the perineum, external genitalia, and perianal region. 

Risk factors include immunocompromised states such as

  • HIV
  • Alcoholism
  • Diabetes (the SGLT-2 inhibitors currently available are canagliflozin, dapagliflozin, and empagliflozin which can also cause Fournier's Gangrene)

The infection may be precipitated by minor procedures in the perineal area, such as a bruise, scratch, urethral dilatation, injection of hemorrhoids, or opening of a periurethral abscess. The infection spreads along the dartos, Scarpa's, and Colle's fascia.

The sequence of events that lead to the development of gangrene are as follows: A mixed infection of the aerobic and anaerobic bacteria  → fulminating inflammation of subcutaneous tissue → obliterative arteritis of the arterioles that supply the scrotal skin → gangrene. Thus, a black scrotum with crepitus can be seen as shown in the image below.

Clinical features include pain out of proportion to physical examination findings, fever, prostration, and pallor. Cellulitis spreads rapidly and may be associated with eschars, necrosis, flaking skin, and crepitus. The testis is usually not affected, and hence, it is also called shameful exposure of the testis. It is a surgical emergency.

Diagnosis is primarily clinical and very rarely made by laboratory or imaging findings. 

Management involves the administration of IV fluids, broad-spectrum antibiotics, and urgent surgical debridement. When the infection has been controlled, the vacuum-assisted dressing may be helpful.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old man with head trauma was brought in an unconscious state to the emergency. After some time, the patient regained his consciousness and then he again started to deteriorate rapidly. His head CT is as below. This patient can be managed conservatively if:

Criteria

  1. Clot volume <30 cm3
  2. Maximum thickness <1.5 cm
  3. GCS >8

choices.text: Patient meets either 1 or 2 along with GCS >12

questions.solution:
The presence of lucid interval in this patient and the CT image showing a biconvex/lentiform hemorrhage are suggestive of extradural hematoma. The above CT scan shows a large extradural hematoma (hyperdense biconvex/lentiform shape) with a mass effect. 

Craniotomy is indicated for EDH. But, patients who meet all of the following criteria may be managed conservatively:

  • Clot volume < 30 cc
  • Maximum thickness < 1.5 cm
  • Glasgow coma score > 8

EDH refers to the accumulation of blood in the potential space between the inner table of the skull and the dura mater. It is common in young adults. It is rare in children below 2 years of age because of the plasticity of the immature calvarium, and after age 60 because the dura is adherent to the overlying bone.

The hematoma arises from arterial disruption, especially of the middle meningeal artery. The middle meningeal vein and diploic veins may also be implicated.

A lucid interval is not pathognomonic for EDH as other post-traumatic mass lesions like a subdural hematoma, and temporal lobe contusion can also present with a lucid interval. Uncal herniation from an EDH classically causes ipsilateral third nerve palsy and contralateral hemiparesis.

On head CT, the blood clot is bright, biconvex or lentiform in shape, and has a well-defined border. An EDH is typically found over the convexities but may rarely occur in the posterior fossa as well.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: As per the Milan criteria for liver transplantation in patients with cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma, which of the following would disqualify a patient for liver transplantation?

choices.text: Presence of a single tumor with diameter 4.2 cm
Presence of three tumors with diameters 2.5 cm, 2.2 cm, and 1.5 cm
Presence of two tumors with diameter 2.2 cm and 1.5 cm

questions.solution:
The presence of major vessel involvement would disqualify a patient for liver transplantation, as per the Milan criteria.

The Milan criteria are used to assess the suitability of patients with cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma for liver transplantation. In order to be suitable for liver transplantation, the patient should have

  • a single tumor with a diameter of ≤5 cm
  • up to 3 tumors, each with a diameter ≤3 cm
  • no extra-hepatic involvement
  • no macrovascular invasion

questions.text:
You are an intern posted in the surgery department. You are told to perform urethral catheterization for a male patient who is unable to void urine. What are the steps you would follow while performing this procedure?
  1. Lidocaine gel is instilled into the urethra.
  2. Catheter should be inserted until the hilt and the position is confirmed with the drainage of clear urine.
  3. Urethral meatus is cleaned with an antiseptic solution.
  4. Catheter bag should be attached.
  5. The balloon should be inflated with 10 mL of sterile water.
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of urethral catheterization is:

  • 3. Urethral meatus is cleaned with an antiseptic solution.
  • 1. Lidocaine gel is instilled into the urethra.   
  • 2. Catheter should be inserted until the hilt and the position is confirmed with the drainage of clear urine. 
  • 5. The balloon should be inflated with 10 mL of sterile water.
  • 4. Catheter bag should be attached.

Before inserting the catheter, handwashing is done followed by wearing sterile gloves. Then the urethral meatus is cleaned with an antiseptic solution. Lidocaine gel is instilled into the urethra. In men, the penis should be held perpendicular, while in women, the labia should be held apart to produce adequate exposure of the meatus. The catheter should be inserted until the hilt of the catheter. In case of resistance, the procedure is stopped and assistance is sought. The position of the catheter in the bladder is confirmed with the drainage of clear urine and the balloon should be inflated with 10 mL of sterile water. Following the confirmation, the catheter bag should be attached. Details about the type and size of the catheter, and residual volume, should be clearly recorded.

 

Related Pearl: Foley's Catheter

A Foley catheter is a thin, sterile tube inserted into the bladder to drain urine. Because it can be left in place in the bladder for a period of time, it is also called an indwelling catheter.

French scale corresponds to the outer diameter in millimetres, and 1Fr is 0.3 mm in diameter.

Fr. size = 3 x d, where d is the outer diameter in mm. 

A 18 Fr. catheter will have a circumference of approximately 18 mm and a diameter of 6 mm.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency room following blunt abdominal trauma. On examination, he was hemodynamically stable. Contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) showed splenic trauma with a subcapsular hematoma over 30% of the surface area with ongoing hemorrhage. Angiography and embolization were done but failed to achieve hemostasis. Which of the following is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The next step in management is splenorrhaphy. 

The non-expanding subcapsular hematoma over 30% of the surface area is suggestive of grade II splenic injury. These patients are managed by angiography and embolization, and if it fails, the next step in management is a spleen-saving technique or splenorrhaphy.

Splenorrhaphy is a procedure done to preserve the spleen parenchyma. These involve all the surgical procedures done to save the spleen parenchyma while splenectomy is the entire surgical removal of the viscera. Splenorrhaphy should not be performed if the patient is unstable if there are multiple injuries or extensive splenic injury. 

Grades of splenic injury:

Grade Injury
I Non-expanding subcapsular hematoma (<10% of surface area) or laceration, <1 cm of parenchymal depth
II Non-expanding subcapsular hematoma (10-50% of surface area) or laceration, 1-3 cm of parenchymal depth which does not involve the trabecular vessels
III

Hematoma > 50% of surface area or expanding

  • Ruptured subcapsular or parenchymal hematoma,
  • Intraparenchymal hematoma >5 cm or expanding Or
    Laceration, >3 cm parenchymal depth or involving
    trabecular vessels
IV Laceration involving segmental or hilar vessels leading to major devascularization (>25% of the spleen)
V Shattered spleen
or
A hilar vascular injury that devascularizes the spleen.

Management of splenic trauma:

Grade I and II injuries:

They are usually hemodynamically stable and are managed non-operatively. Initially, these patients are managed conservatively with regular monitoring of vitals, hematocrit, and serial CECT.

If the grade of injury is found to increase, then angiography and embolization of the bleeding vessel are done to achieve hemostasis. If angiography and embolization fail to achieve hemostasis, or if the patient becomes hemodynamically unstable, then a splenorrhaphy is done.

Grade III injuries that are hemodynamically stable are managed like that of grades I and II, while those that are hemodynamically unstable are managed like that of grades IV and V.

Grade IV and V injuries patients are usually hemodynamically unstable and splenectomy is done.

Other options: 

Option A: Repeat angiography and embolization are unlikely to help as it has already failed once in this patient. 

Option B: Conservative management will not stop the ongoing hemorrhage that is present in this patient. It is useful in patients who are no longer bleeding. 

Option C: Splenectomy is not required in this patient as they have a grade II injury and are still hemodynamically stable.

Related Pearl: American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) Spleen Injury Scale

Related Pearl: Indications for Selective Non-Operative Management (SNOM) in splenic trauma

Indications :

  • Patient younger than 55 years
  • Grade I, II, or III (in selective cases) splenic injury
  • Physiologic stability, as indicated by normal blood pressure, lack of tachycardia, absence of physical examination findings indicating shock, and absence of metabolic acidosis.
